name: First-Year Seminar: Organizing and Communicating for Social Entrepreneurs
desc: This course examines the historical and current development of social entrepreneurship as a field of study and practice, with particular attention to successful organizational communication strategies designed to solve community problems.

name: First-Year Seminar: Collective Leadership Models for Community Change
desc: This course will explore communication models for collective leadership involving youth and adults in vulnerable communities. Partnering with local youth-focused organizations, students will work in teams to research and design community-based change projects.

name: First-Year Seminar: Is There Life after College?: The Meaning of Work in Contemporary Life
desc: Examines the historical emergence of work as a defining feature of contemporary life. The course asks, What is a career"? How have neoliberalism and post-Fordism influenced understandings of work and career?  How have changing conceptions of work influenced other aspects of life
Repeat: consumption

name: First-Year Seminar: The Politics of Performance
desc: In this course students will explore the possibilities of making political performances, or making performances political. We will be particularly concerned with how performance may contribute to processes of social change.

name: First-Year Seminar: African American Literature and Performance
desc: This course examines the question of what characterizes Blackness" as it manifests through experience
GenEd: and symbol in the United States
Repeat: as well as the impact of African practices and identities upon blackness in the United States. The course is concerned with what has been termed the "black literary imagination"."

name: First-Year Seminar: The Creative Process in Performance
desc: Students will be engaged with multimedia, music, dance, and theater performances. We will explore the creative processes and cultural contexts of these performances and will compare the arts as a way of knowing the world to the creative processes of academic scholarship.

name: First-Year Seminar: Understanding Place through Rhetoric
desc: This seminar explores how we come to understand what places are and how they are meaningful. We will look at places rhetorically": how they were designed to persuade those who inhabit them
GenEd: and how we make sense of them in our individual lives."

name: First-Year Seminar: Food Politics from an Organizational Communication Perspective
desc: This course provides an applied introduction to food politics by adopting a critical organizational communication lens on our globalized food system. We explore food system labor practices, the role of multinational companies and global commodity chains, the status of hunger and food deserts, the role of food marketing and consumption practices, and the growth of local and sustainable movements devoted to food justice.

name: First-Year Seminar: Networked Societies
desc: This seminar is designed to introduce early-career students to the role that networks play in contemporary global societies. We will examine key ways to think about network societies by taking up the idea of the network in social, political, economic, cultural, and technological terms.

name: First-Year Seminar: Think, Speak, Argue
desc: This is a course in learning to think more critically, speak more persuasively, and argue more effectively by focusing on practical skill development in reasoning and debate.

name: First-Year Seminar: Surveillance and Society
desc: How are surveillance technologies altering social life? This course will explore this question by mapping the complex ways that technologies and societies interact to produce security, fear, control, vulnerability, and/or empowerment.

name: First-Year Seminar: Technologies of Popular Culture
desc: This seminar takes an historical approach to the relationship between popular culture and technological change. We will explore how artists and other workers (including audiences) in the TV, smart phone, and especially music industries have incorporated new technology into the production, distribution, and consumption of cultural commodities and experiences.

name: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics
desc: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester. Honors version available
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Communication and Social Process
desc: Addresses the many ways our communication--including language, discourse, performance, and media--reflects, creates, sustains, and transforms prevailing social and cultural practices.

name: Public Speaking
desc: Theory and extensive practice in various types of speaking.

name: Introduction to Interpersonal and Organizational Communication
desc: An introduction to communication theory, research, and practice in a variety of interpersonal and organizational contexts. This course examines the role of communication in both personal and professional relationships. Honors version available

name: Introduction to Media Production
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Prerequisite for all production courses. Introduces students to basic tools, techniques, and conventions of production in audio, video, and film.

name: Writing for the Screen and Stage
desc: Restricted course.  Dramatic writing workshop open only to students in the writing for the screen and stage minor.

name: Introduction to Media History, Theory, and Criticism
desc: An introduction to the critical analysis of film, television, advertising, video, and new media texts, contexts, and audiences. Honors version available

name: Popular Music
desc: This class explores the historical, social, political, and cultural significances of popular music as a communicative practice in the United States from 1950 to the present.

name: Introduction to New Media
desc: An introduction to the design, aesthetics, and analysis of various forms of digital media. Hands-on experience with different modes of creation, including graphics, web-based communication, and social media.

name: Introduction to Performance Studies
desc: As the introductory course in performance studies, students will explore and experiment with performance as ritual, performance in everyday life, and the performance of literature. Honors version available

name: Rhetoric and Public Issues
desc: Examines the basic nature and importance of rhetoric and argumentation. Attention is devoted to interpreting the persuasive function of texts and their relation to modern forms of life.

name: Argumentation and Debate
desc: Analysis of issues, use of evidence, reasoning, briefmaking, and refutation. Argumentative speeches and debates on legal cases and on current events. Designed for prospective law students, public policy students, speech teachers, and college debaters.

name: Small Group Communication
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to the theory and practice of communication in the small group setting. Topics may include group development, conformity and deviation, gender, problem solving, and power and leadership.

name: Introduction to Gender and Communication
desc: Examines multiple relationships among gender, communication and culture. Explores how communication creates gender and shapes relationships and how communication reflects, sustains, and alters cultural views of gender. Honors version available

name: Audio/Video/Film Production and Writing
desc: The material, processes, and procedures of audio, video, and film production; emphasis on the control of those elements of convention that define form in the appropriate medium. Lecture and laboratory hours.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, COMM 130 and 140; Grade of C or better in COMM 130; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: Introduction to Communication Technology, Culture, and Society
desc: Historical exploration of the sociocultural import of communication technologies, from the introduction of the telegraph in the mid-1800s through current implications of the Internet and various digital devices.

name: Introduction to American Film and Culture, 1965-Present
desc: An introduction to some key connections between American film history and cultural history since 1965, most of which remain backbones of United States film culture to this day.

name: Introduction to Performance and Social Change
desc: This course addresses the relationship between performance and power, focusing on topics concerned with the potential for performance to contribute to social change.

name: Introduction to the Performance of Culture
desc: Introduces students to performance as a way of studying culture in all of its creative, dynamic forms, including family stories, joking, rituals, and practices of everyday life. The course emphasizes field methods and experiential research. Honors version available

name: Performing Literature
desc: Introduction to the study and practice of performing literature. Students will create, rehearse, and stage performances that draw on fiction, poetry, non-fiction, and/or memoir. Honors version available

name: Persuasion
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Examines contemporary theory and practice of influencing others' attitudes, beliefs, and actions. Focuses particularly on analyzing and developing persuasive messages.

name: Cultural Diversity
desc: Introduction to basic paradigms of thinking about cultural difference, encouraging students to examine how these paradigms shape how we think, act, and imagine ourselves/others as members of diverse cultures.

name: Introduction to Organizational Communication
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. The course explores the historical and theoretical developments in the research and practice of organizational communication. Honors version available

name: Introduction to Writing for Film and Television
desc: An introduction to screenwriting for film and television.

name: Writing the Short Film
desc: Students practice and learn the craft of narrative, short film writing by conceptualizing, outlining, writing, and rewriting three short film scripts. They include one three-minute silent, one five-minute script with dialogue, and one 15-minute script with dialogue.

name: Writing the One-Hour TV Drama
desc: Students in this class will live the life of a writing staff on a just-picked-up, fictional, one-hour television series. As if on a real series, they will individually and cooperatively create story ideas, treatments, and outlines, as well as write scenes, acts, and entire scripts.

name: Film Story Analysis
desc: A variety of feature films (both domestic and foreign) are screened in class and analyzed from a storytelling perspective. Emphasis is on the range of possibilities the screenwriter and film director face in the process of managing the audience's emotional involvement in a story.

name: Visual Storytelling for Screenwriters
desc: Priority given to majors. This course instructs students on how to tell stories in a visual manner. How do the words on a page get translated onto a screen and how will the writer collaborate visually with a director? It is designed for writers to better understand how their scripts are interpreted and to improve visual writing.

name: Gender and Film
desc: This course examines the representations of women in contemporary American film and also considers women as producers of film.

name: Practices of Cultural Studies
desc: Introduces students to the history, methods, and central intellectual questions of cultural studies.

name: Terrorism and Political Violence
desc: This course is a multi-disciplinary analysis of the phenomena of terrorism and political violence, their history, causes, the threat they pose, and what steps the United States can take in response.

name: Social Media and Society
desc: This class examines the relationship between society and computer-mediated communication technologies known as social media
Prereqs: including Facebook, Snapchat, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and more. It aims to break down the mythologies of social media and develop methods of analysis and critical understanding. Drawing from communication, sociology, anthropology, and cultural studies, students will understand social media's role within a larger social context.

name: Ritual, Theatre, and Performance Art
desc: Explores how each of these forms of performance communicates meaning and feeling and points to possibility. Students develop performances in each mode, informed by readings in anthropology and directing theory.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 160; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Production Practices
desc: This course introduces students to the process of creating and producing technical aspects for live performance. Students engage in all practical and artistic aspects of production. Course includes a laboratory requirement.

name: The Constructed Actor: Masks and Objects in Performance
desc: This course provides a performance-based instruction in the development of mask, puppet, and performing object skills.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 160; DRAM 135, 145, or 150; EXSS 191; or PHYA 224.

name: Argumentation
desc: This course examines the theory and practice of argument and deliberation in communication studies, drawing from resources in rhetorical studies, informal logic, and argumentation. Intended for pre-law, public policy and other students interested in argumentation.

name: The Rhetoric of Social Movements
desc: Explores the discourse of dissident voices in American society, particularly as they speak about grievances pertaining to race, gender, the environment; focuses on rhetorical strategies that initiate and sustain social movements.

name: The Southern Experience in Rhetoric
desc: Examines recurrent themes in the rhetoric of significant Southerners and important campaigns. Considers both the rhetoric of the establishment and the rhetoric of change.

name: Environmental Advocacy
desc: Explores rhetorical means of citizen influence of practices affecting our natural and human environment; also, study of communication processes and dilemmas of redress of environmental grievances in communities and workplace.

name: The Rhetoric of War and Peace
desc: Explores philosophical assumptions and social values expressed by advocates of war and peace through a critical examination of such rhetorical acts as speeches, essays, film, literature, and song.

name: Dance and Embodied Knowledge in the Indian Context
desc: In this theory-practice course focusing on religion, performance, and South Asian studies we will analyze the nature of embodied knowledge, aesthetic theory, and the creative power of dance performance in the Indian context. The course also includes a practical component involving embodied experience with Indian classical dance forms.

name: Disciplining the Body and Mind: The Martial Arts of East Asia in Religion, History, and Culture
desc: This course offers an introduction to the history and practice of East Asian martial arts. We will explore the social, political, and cultural contexts of the martial arts, from the classical period to the present. Integral to this course is a practical component involving embodied experience with martial arts training.

name: Special Topics in Communication Study
desc: A special topics course on a selected aspect of communication studies.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Internships
desc: Permission of the department. Majors only. 2.5 cumulative grade point average required. Individualized study closely supervised by a faculty advisor and by the departmental coordinator of internships. Cannot count toward the COMM major.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Independent Study and Directed Research
desc: Permission of the department. Majors only. 3.0 cumulative grade point average and 3.5 communication studies grade point average required. For communication studies majors who wish to pursue independent research projects or reading programs under the supervision of a selected instructor. Intensive individual research on a problem designed by instructor and student in conference.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Critical Perspectives
desc: This course explores theories of criticism and symbolic action through readings, lecture, and practical criticism of literature, media, discourse, and other symbolic acts.

name: Critical Theory
desc: An introduction to European modern and contemporary philosophy, from the enlightenment to contemporary postmodernism.

name: Freud
desc: Examination of Freudian thought within and across historical contexts, with special attention to the centrality of gender and sexuality in the operations of the human organism.""

name: Family Communication
desc: Growth in technologies, more frequent travel, and movements of products and people across the borders of nation states change concepts of family and community. Foregrounded by these realities, this course combines theories of family and communication with documentation of lived experience to interrogate family communication patterns in contemporary culture. Honors version available

name: Critical Perspectives on Work, Labor, and Professional Life
desc: This upper level seminar develops a critical perspective on work, labor, and professional life within the global context. Throughout, we will engage in moral and philosophical debates about the status of labor and the meanings of work in our daily lives.

name: History of American Screenwriting
desc: This viewing and research-intensive course examines the history of American narrative film through the screenwriter's experience, using a decade-by-decade approach to examine the political, social, global, psychological, religious, and cultural influences on the art, process, and careers of screenwriters.

name: Advanced Audio Production
desc: Advanced analysis and application of the principles and methods of audio production.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 130 or 150; Grade of C or better in COMM 130; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Visual Culture
desc: Course provides an overview of theories of visual culture. We apply these theories to better understand contemporary visual media and technologies, along with the everyday media practices they support.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 140; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Intermediate Screenwriting
desc: Open only to students in the writing for the screen and stage minor. Conceiving and outlining a feature-length screenplay.

name: Memory Acts
desc: Advanced introduction to foundational work in memory and performance studies, emphasizing theory and practice of various forms of remembering. Honors version available

name: United States Black Culture and Performance
desc: Examines how the United States Black experience is constituted in and through performance across a range of cultural contexts including the antebellum South, Reconstruction, the Harlem Renaissance, the Black Aesthetic, and contemporary urban life.

name: Media and Popular Culture
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Examination of communication processes and cultural significance of film, television, and other electronic media.

name: Film Noir
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Course combines reading about and viewing of 1940s and 1950s films combining narrative techniques of storytelling, novels, and the stage with purely filmic uses of spectacle, light, editing, and image.

name: The History of New Media Technology in Everyday Life
desc: The starting point for this course, chronologically and conceptually, is the emergence of popular media technology. Our purview includes transformative innovations in mediated communication, such as telephony and e-mail, alongside familiar media technologies such as televisions and computers.

name: Media and Activism
desc: A study of the electronic media as a feedback mechanism for community organization and social change. A variety of broadcast and nonbroadcast uses of the media are studied.

name: Creating the Solo Performance
desc: This course examines processes of creating and performing solo work. Students engage a variety of performances: autobiographical, representation of the lives of other/s, and exploration of cultural or political ideas.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 160, DRAM 120, or ENGL 206, 207, or 208; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Collaborative Performance
desc: Theory and practice of collaborative performance, emphasizing image, intertextual adaptation, site-specific and installation work, avant-garde traditions, and the play of time and space. Honors version available

name: Advanced Study in Performing Literature
desc: This course engages the theory and embodiment of prose fiction, poetry, and other kinds of literary texts, including nonfiction. Students practice adaptation and script preparation, solo/group performance, and performance critique.

name: Political Communication and the Public Sphere
desc: A course covering the relationship between communication and political processes and institutions. Topics include media coverage and portrayal of political institutions, elections, actors, and media influence on political beliefs.

name: Rhetorics of Public Memory
desc: Takes up the fundamental assumptions of contemporary memory studies and the centrality of rhetoric to memory.  Research focus on how constructions of the past respond to the present and future.

name: Rhetorical Criticism
desc: Approaches to the analysis and assessment of rhetorical practice with a focus on how rhetoric reflects and shapes public culture.

name: Special Topics in Communication Studies
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. A special topics course on a selected aspect of communication studies.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: The Dark Side of Interpersonal Communication
desc: The dark side" of communication is a metaphor describing the study of disruptive
Repeat: distressing
Grading: and destructive aspects of communication. This course explores humanity's darker side that allows us to reject
column15: and cheat. The course examines various theoretical perspectives and applies them to everyday problems in interpersonal encounters. A sample of topics discussed include: prejudice

name: Visual and Material Rhetoric
desc: This course explores the use of rhetorical criticism as a way to understand how the visual and material are used for symbolic and political purposes. Examples ranging from news images to public art will be studied.

name: Communication and Social Memory
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. An investigation of psychological aspects of communication, particularly the perceptual and interpretive processes underlying the sending and receiving of messages.

name: Communication and Leadership
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Critical examination of alternative theories of leadership and trends in the study of leadership; focuses on the communicative dimensions of leadership.

name: Gender, Communication, and Culture
desc: Course examines the speeches and other texts that announced and embodied the goals and political strategies of multiple branches of three waves of feminist activism in the United States.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 224; permission of the instructor for non-majors.

name: Organizational Communication
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Provides a critical exploration of organizational communication theory, research, and application, examining the factors involved in the functioning and analysis of complex organizations.

name: Critical-Cultural Approaches to Organizational Communication
desc: The study of organizational culture operates on a set of assumptions distinct from traditional management perspectives. This course explores the cultural perspective as an alternative approach to understanding organizational communication processes.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 325; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Organizational Ethics
desc: A critical examination of the theory, research, and practice of organizational ethics.

name: Performing the Screenplay
desc: Introduces students to approaches for creating performance from screenplays and other texts for electronic media forms, focusing on scripts as literature and the tensions between live and electronically delivered performances.

name: Aesthetic and Technical Considerations in Making Short Videos
desc: The course examines the aesthetic and technical elements at work and play in cinematic storytelling. The student is required to complete three projects and will gain hands-on experience in narrative filmmaking.

name: Introduction to Screen Adaptation
desc: Students practice the craft of screen adaptation by conceptualizing, outlining, and writing scenes based on material from another medium (both fiction and nonfiction). Work is presented, discussed, and performed in a workshop environment.

name: Master Screenwriting
desc: Open only to students in the writing for the screen and stage minor. Students will write and workshop a full-length feature film screenplay. Students will learn about the film and television business through a combination of research, in-class discussions, and interactive interviews with industry insiders.

name: Pornography and Culture
desc: Examines the social, cultural, political, legal, historical, and aesthetic implications of pornography.

name: History of Film I, 1895 to 1945
desc: Studies the development of the art of film through World War II by examining individual films and filmmakers and the emergence of national cinemas through interaction among aesthetic, social, economic, and technological factors.

name: History of Film II, 1945 to Present
desc: Study of the development of the art of film from the end of World War II to the present day by examining individual films and filmmakers and the emergence of national cinemas through interaction among aesthetic, social, economic, and technological factors.

name: Humor and Culture
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Investigates how humor, comedy, and laughter function socially and culturally through close examination of selected United States popular media texts and the primary modern theoretical writings on these issues.

name: Sexuality and Visual Culture
desc: Examines questions about sexuality and how it has changed over time, through various media of visual communication.

name: American Independent Cinema
desc: Intensive investigation of some particularly influential strains for United States independent narrative cinema, with a focus on sociocultural contexts and the fuzziness of the word independent.""
Prereqs: Prerequisite, ARTH 159, COMM 140, or ENGL 142; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Hitchcock and the Sign
desc: Course gives Alfred Hitchcock's cinema careful attention while tracking longstanding debates about signification and reference from philosophy, semiotics, literary theory, narratology, and visuality into recent critical and cultural theory.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, ARTH 159, COMM 140, or ENGL 142; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Performance of Women of Color
desc: Explores through performance contemporary poetry, fiction, nonfiction, and feminist thought by women of color in the United States. Honors version available

name: Oral History and Performance
desc: This course combines readings and field work in oral history with the study of performance as a means of interpreting and conveying oral history texts. Honors version available
Grading: Letter gradeSame as: FOLK 562, HIST 562, WGST 562.

name: Performance and Popular Culture
desc: Critical examination of the operation of performance as a cultural phenomenon, with an emphasis on meaning, power,  and resistance in cultural events, social practices, and media spectacles.

name: Adapting and Directing for the Stage
desc: This course introduces students to practices in adapting and directing literary texts for live ensemble performance. Students will create original performance work, engage in collaborative critique, and discuss the development of aesthetic value.

name: Rhetorical Theory and Practice
desc: Investigates the theoretical definitions and uses of rhetorical interpretation and action in spoken, written, visual, material practices, discourses, and events.

name: Public Policy Argument
desc: Analyzes argument in a variety of contexts with an emphasis on public policy and exploring tensions involved in addressing both expert and public audience in the political sphere. Honors version available

name: The American Experience in Rhetoric
desc: Examines public discourse from the colonial period to the present. Discourses, critical perspectives, and historical periods studied will vary.

name: War and Culture
desc: Examines American cultural myths about war generally and specifically about the causes of war, enemies, weapons, and warriors, and the way these myths constrain foreign and defense policy, military strategy, and procurement.

name: Presidential Rhetoric
desc: The power of the presidency depends in part upon the president's ability to rally public opinion, which depends upon the president's ability to use the bully pulpit." This course examines the hurdles presidents face and the steps presidents take to shape opinion."

name: Making and Manipulating Race" in the United States"
desc: This course will examine how tropes of race" are symbolically invented and experienced psychologically and emotionally. This course assesses how "race" reflects and shapes cultural politics."

name: Rhetoric and Black Culture
desc: This course will explore the complex ways in which Black aesthetic forms and creative expression function as public discourse.

name: Advanced Independent Study/Directed Reading
desc: Permission of the department. Majors only. 3.0 cumulative grade point average and 3.5 communication studies grade point average required. For the communication studies major who wishes to pursue an advanced independent research project under the supervision of a selected instructor. Intensive individual research on a problem designed by instructor and student in conference.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Reading Quantitative Research in Communication Studies
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Review of the basics of quantitative research (e.g., scientific method, modes of data collection, instrument development, data analysis techniques) with the goal of gaining skill in reading published articles in communication studies journals.

name: Theories of Interpersonal Communication
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Course focuses on how communication is used to build and sustain interpersonal relationships. Forms and functions of communication are examined as a means of testing and defining relationships.

name: Hate Speech
desc: The primary focus of hate speech is on the ways that interactants manipulate hatred to accomplish a variety of social and personal goals. The pursuit of this focus will allow the student to appreciate the operation of hatred in a variety of contexts. Often taught as a service-learning course.

name: Communication and Nonprofits in the Global Context
desc: Introduces students to the opportunities, challenges, and rewards of participation within the nonprofit/NGO sector. The course also equips students with the skills needed to design and conduct engaged scholarship.
GenEd: EE- Service Learning, EE- Mentored Research, GL.

name: Documentary Production
desc: A workshop in the production of video and/or film nonfiction or documentary projects. The course will focus on narrative, representational, and aesthetic strategies of documentary production.

name: Interactive Media
desc: Explores interactive media through creative projects that include sound, video, and graphic elements. Technical information will serve the broader goal of understanding the aesthetics and critical issues of interactive media.

name: Social Practice and Performance Art
desc: Students will explore socially engaged art" practices that challenge the distinction between art and life
Repeat: and utilize action
column9: and participation as strategies as an intervention in public discourse."

name: Game Design
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Studio course that explores gaming critically and aesthetically. Practice in game design and production including 3-D worlds and scripting.

name: Game Studio
desc: Game Studio is a project-based course in the new media track. This course is designed to provide a structured environment, instructor and peer feedback, along with technical and conceptual resources in which to complete a new media project. Students may work individually or on collaborative teams. The class focuses on idea development, design, and experimentation.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 638; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Special Topics in Cultural Studies
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. This course will explore various specific topics, theories, and methodologies in cultural studies.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Documentary Production: First Person Filmmaking
desc: Students create documentaries emphasizing the filmmaker's personal perspective and experience: essay, diary, and autobiographical films, and pieces in which the filmmaker performs a role for expressive or political ends. Significant class time is devoted to work-shopping student films.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 230; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: The Documentary Idea
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Historical and theoretical examination of expressions of the documentary idea in different eras and various modes including film, television, and radio.

name: Introduction to the Art and Mechanics of Two-Dimensional Digital Animation
desc: Students use Adobe After-Effects and Adobe Photoshop as their primary image software to create several original animations. Assignments are given weekly, and a substantial final project is expected.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 130 or 150; Grade of C or better required in COMM 130.

name: Advanced Projects in Media Production
desc: Recommended preparation, several production courses above COMM 230. Course provides a structured environment, instructor and peer feedback, along with production and postproduction resources for completing advanced near-to-graduation media projects. Projects can be narrative, documentary, experimental, or interactive.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, COMM 230 and one of COMM 534, 635, 646, 653, or 654.

name: Cultural Politics of Global Media Culture
desc: Primary subjects will be popular culture and media technology, and guiding questions will be organized around the relationships of each to commerce and/as social change.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 140; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Media and Difference
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. This course examines critical and theoretical issues concerning the representation and study of various modes of difference, such as sexuality, race, and gender, in specific media texts.

name: Experimental Video
desc: This course allows students to create video productions that play with forms that lie outside of mainstream media.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 230; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Motion Graphics, Special Effects, and Compositing
desc: In this course students learn a wide range of video post production techniques working mostly with the application After Effects.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 130 or 150; Grade of C or better in COMM 130; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Television Culture
desc: This course introduces students to critical television studies. The course emphasizes not television or culture as separate entities but instead Television Culture." The focus of the class is on the interrelationship between television and contemporary culture."

name: Sound for Film and Video: Theory and Practice for Motion Picture Sound Design
desc: The aim of this course is to provide students who have an interest in film and video production with an understanding of the technical, conceptual, and aesthetic implications of the motion picture soundtrack, with a special emphasis on sound-image relationships. Students who have already developed a basic proficiency in the use of video cameras, audio recorders, and editing software will be asked to cultivate an understanding of and appreciation for the expressive and artistic possibilities.

name: Movie Making Machines: Learning About Cinema in the Maker Space
desc: This projects-based seminar will introduce students to the fundamental optical and technological principles of motion pictures. By using the Maker Space to design and fabricate pinhole cameras, zoetropes, and 16mm film strips, students will gain a deep understanding of the material and technological foundations of the cinema, and the operating principles that are behind not only the classic films of Hollywood's past, but the high-definition digital imaging technologies of the present.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, ARTS 105, 106, 209, or COMM 130; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Advanced Projects in Performance Studies
desc: Course provides a workshop setting for the process of creation, dramaturgy, development, analysis, and critique of graduates' and undergraduates' original performance work, focusing on the needs of each project in progress.

name: Race and Ethnicity
desc: Examines race and ethnicity in specific geopolitical contexts as discursive formations, performative identities, and lived realities. Studies disciplinary/political boundaries that are produced and maintained through acts of performance.

name: Black/African Diaspora Performance
desc: Recommended preparation, COMM 160. Relying on critical race theories, colonial and postcolonial theories, and theories of performance, this course engages comparative discourses of Black/African diaspora citizenship through the literature, poetry, fiction, nonfiction, drama, and cultural performances of people of African descent, particularly in Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

name: Performance, Politics, and Culture
desc: This course is a arts-based inquiry into the ways in which performance and theatricality structure contemporary politics, culture, and everyday life, as well as the ways in which artists utilize performance as mode of political engagement.

name: Media in Performance
desc: Required preparation, one performance studies course above COMM 400. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the required preparation.  Project-based class where students acquire skills and critical approaches to create collaborative, professional, multimedia works.

name: Performance Activism
desc: History and practice of performance in contemporary social movements.  Practical exploration of direct action, guerilla theatre, and performance interventions.

name: The Ethnographic Return to Performance and Community
desc: This course will explore the multiple ways in which performance practiced across a broad range of social, cultural, and artistic arenas can support local community life. Honors version available

name: Digital Media and Live Performance
desc: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Intended for students from various majors, this course provides a foundation in the history, theory, and practice of developing live, technologically-intensive, multimedia performance works. The course analyzes new media masterworks, addresses techniques of interdisciplinary collaboration, and offers workshops in specific software/technology applications.

name: Contemporary Film Theory
desc: Overview of poststructuralist, or contemporary" film theory. Traces its development
GenEd: fierce critiques lobbed at it since the early 1980s
Repeat: and its points of continuing importance."
Grading: Prerequisite, ARTH 159, COMM 140, or ENGL 142; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: History of the Moving Image: Pasts, Presents, Futures
desc: Theories of moving images and imaging technologies--from the primitive to the not-yet-existing--that focus on their multifaceted relations with various registers of time, memory, flux, and futurity.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, ARTH 159, COMM 140, or ENGL 142; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Moving-Image Avant-Gardes and Experimentalism
desc: History and theory of international avant-garde and experimentalist movements in film, video, intermedia, multimedia, and digital formats. Content and focus may vary from semester to semester.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, ARTH 159, COMM 140, or ENGL 142; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Advanced Topics in Communication Studies
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. A special topics course on a selected aspect of communication studies. May be repeated. Honors version available
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Honors in Cultural Studies
desc: Permission of the instructor. Required of all senior honors candidates in cultural studies. First semester of senior honors thesis.

name: Honors in Cultural Studies
desc: Permission of the instructor. Required of all senior honors candidates in cultural studies. Second semester of senior honors thesis.

name: Honors
desc: Permission of the department. Majors only. Cumulative grade point average must meet University standard. Individual projects designed by students and supervised by a faculty member.

name: Honors
desc: Permission of the department. Majors only. Cumulative grade point average must meet University standard. Individual projects designed by students and supervised by a faculty member.

name: Field Methods
desc: Recommended preparation, COMM 562 or 841. A bridge course designed to offer graduate students and advanced undergraduates a practicum in fieldwork methods and performance ethnography.

name: Introduction to Modern Philosophy and Contemporary Theory
desc: Considers the emergence of modern and contemporary social and cultural theory. Surveys major paradigms of modern and contemporary philosophy.

name: Introduction to Research and Theory in Communication Studies II
desc: Admission to graduate program or permission of the department. Considers theory and philosophy in the study of communication. Surveys major paradigms of contemporary social/cultural theory (and their roots in modern philosophy) in relation to examples of communication research and practice. Second of two semesters.

name: Teaching in Communication Studies
desc: Communication studies graduate students only. An introduction to teaching at the university level for new teaching assistants and graduate students hoping to have teaching-related responsibilities in communication studies. It is designed to encourage us to have intellectually rigorous and personally meaningful conversations about our teaching.

name: Communication and the Political
desc: This course is designed for students to start thinking, in a historical and foundational way, about 'the political' as defined by formative thinkers from contrasting philosophical perspectives, as well as from necessarily different social positions within the field of power.

name: Communication and Discourse
desc: This course focuses on the various ways that the problem of discourse is rendered inside and outside of Communication Studies. It examines the various modes at our disposal for thinking about discourse as a field of articulation: for example in theories of representation, mediation, and meaning making.

name: Communication and the Social
desc: This class theorizes the Social by drawing on resources inside and outside of communication studies, thinking through the implicit and explicit investments that communication scholarship has in the concept of the social.

name: Performance as Method
desc: Course introduces graduate students to performance practice as a way of knowing, an aesthetic expression, a form of pedagogy, a method of research, and a means of presenting findings. Students will develop and perform original work that creatively engages various research contexts.

name: The Body and Performance
desc: This course will explore through performance the various ways the human body is 'marked' or signified in culture.

name: Primary Readings in Performance Studies
desc: Course introduces graduate students to key texts that have informed the emergence of Performance Studies as a mode of inquiry into cultural, social, aesthetic, and political practices.

name: Research in Organizational Communication
desc: Explores theoretical, methodological, and practical issues encountered in ethnographic, case study, and field research on communication phenomena in organizations.

name: Feminism, Science, and Communication
desc: Critical examination of key feminist arguments about science and communication scholarship as conventionally defined; exploration of alternative goals, assumptions, and practices for research consistent with feminist theories and methodologies.

name: Interpretive Studies in Organizational Communication
desc: Focuses on the theory and practice of interpretive organizational communication research, including organizational phenomena such as culture, metaphor, symbolism, ritual, and narrative.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 525; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Critical Studies in Organizational Communication
desc: Focuses on the theory and practice of critical organizational communication research, including organizational phenomena such as power, discourse, and culture.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 525; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Cultural Studies
desc: Graduate standing required. Introduction for graduate students to the current literature and critical perspectives in the areas of media and cultural studies.

name: Media and Social Change
desc: This seminar inquires into the range of relationships between media and social life, with a particular emphasis on media's role in movements for social, economic, and/or cultural transformation.

name: Theories of the Audience/Public
desc: This course offers a sustained analysis of the ways in which the media, audience, and/or public have been variously conceptualized historically, in critical theory.

name: Political, Institutional, and Economic Contexts of Media and Culture
desc: A detailed analysis of the relationship between government, policy making, corporate and business interests, and various theoretical approaches to their impact on media and culture. Fall.

name: History of Cultural Studies
desc: This class introduces cultural studies through its British 'origins,' especially but not only the work of the Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies and the Open University.

name: National, International, Transnational, and Global Movie/Media History
desc: Explores the economic, social, ideological, technological, and aesthetic development of film and television as international, transnational, transcultural, and global entities, questioning the viability of the concept of national cinema/media in the 21st century.

name: Studies in Film and Television
desc: Graduate introduction to the study of film, television, and video. This course traces the theoretical and methodological development of media studies.

name: Adaptation Seminar
desc: This seminar recognizes and applies narrative theory in understanding texts, lives, and cultural practice broadly.

name: Topics in Performance Studies
desc: Second-year graduate students and/or permission of the instructor. Special problems in performance studies.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.

name: History of Rhetoric I
desc: A critical survey of the history of rhetoric, focusing on Classical theories of rhetoric from Greece and Rome through the Medieval period.

name: History of Rhetoric II
desc: A critical survey of the history of rhetoric, focusing on theories of rhetoric from the Renaissance through the 19th century.

name: Seminar in Contemporary Rhetorical Theory
desc: A critical survey of the history of rhetoric focusing on rhetorical theory from the 20th century to the present.

name: Visual and Material Rhetorics
desc: Addresses conceptual and practical issues in the rhetorical analysis and criticism of visual and material objects, practices, and events.

name: Seminar in Kenneth Burke
desc: Seminar is an in-depth analysis of the writings of Kenneth Burke, concentrating on primary source materials.

name: Philosophy of Communication and Culture
desc: Considers the history of and developments in the philosophy of communication and culture, as well as the role these concepts have played in western philosophy.

name: Topics in Research Methods
desc: Advanced study of selected topics in research methods. Topics vary.

name: Rhetorical Criticism
desc: Investigates the function of rhetorical criticism, the critical method, and a variety of approaches to the performance of rhetorical criticism.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, COMM 571; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Practicum in Rhetorical Criticism
desc: Focuses on practice in writing rhetorical criticism and on mid-range theoretical concepts that inform critical analysis and argument.

name: Seminar in Family Communication
desc: This course is an advanced seminar in which students may study family communication and produce original research.

name: Seminar in Feminist Studies in Communication
desc: This course compares and critically evaluates the work of major feminist scholars in the field of communication. Spring.

name: Seminar in Interpersonal and Organizational Communication
desc: A variable topic seminar that permits faculty and graduate students the opportunity to explore significant historical and emerging issues in the field of communication.

name: Performance Ethnography
desc: This seminar focuses on methods of ethnography and fieldwork ethics. Performance as theory and practice informs methodological inquiries as well as the analysis of specific ethnographic texts and case studies.

name: Seminar in Performance and Cultural Studies
desc: This course focuses on performance-related issues in the emergent field of cultural studies.

name: Seminar in Contemporary Performance Theory
desc: An advanced graduate seminar, this course will address recent developments and problems in performance theory. It will consider cross- and multidisciplinary approaches to performance as sites for consideration and debate.

name: Seminar in Performance and History
desc: This course explores diverse relations among performance and history, including the performance of life histories, the use of spectacle in history, everyday performances of historical protocols, and performance itself as an historical construct.

name: The Political Economy of Performance
desc: This course examines social relations, particularly power relations, by focusing on resistance as performance and the performance of resistance arising from the dynamics and conflicts within specific locations of a political economy.

name: Performance Pedagogy
desc: Draped in the political, economic, and domestic histories of western culture our current pedagogies still point out the world that matters to each new generation. We will study these pedagogies from the perspectives of institutions, economies, and human relationships they simultaneously reflect and work to transform.

name: Seminar in Culture and Identity
desc: This course looks at issues of the representation and production of identity, subjectivity, and agency - in various forms - in the practices of media.

name: Seminar in Media Studies
desc: Selected problems in media aesthetics. Exact topic to be covered is announced before classes begin.

name: Research Methods in Media and Cultural Studies
desc: Graduate standing required. Introduction to the issues, methods, and materials of research in media and cultural studies.

name: Seminar in the History of Media
desc: Application of historical research techniques to problems in the mass media. Exact topic is announced before classes begin. May be repeated.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.

name: Seminar in Popular Culture
desc: This course will look at special topics in the study of popular culture. Designed for advanced graduate studies, it will consider critical responses to existing scholarship with original research.

name: Seminar in Media Difference
desc: This seminar explores critical theories of difference and puts them into dialogue with media representations of difference.

name: Seminar in Cultural Studies
desc: This class explores the impact of some developments in postmodernism - as an interpretive, historical, and philosophical discourse on the possible development of cultural studies.

name: Seminar in Communication Technology
desc: Examines new communication technologies, their spatial and social diffusion, and how these relate to theories of culture, politics, and technology and the real-world contexts in which technologies are received. May be repeated.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.

name: Seminar in Cultural Studies and Popular Culture
desc: This course will focus on specific topics, issues, or queries of popular culture as these have been or can be studied within cultural studies.

name: Seminar in Feminist Studies of Film and Television
desc: Graduate standing required. This graduate seminar explores theoretical and practical points of contact between feminism, film, and television using psychoanalysis, narrative analysis, ideological analysis, and cultural studies.

name: Seminar in Media and Cultural Studies
desc: This course, designed for advanced graduate students, will explore specialized topics in interpretive, critical, and cultural research in media studies.

name: Aesthetics and Communication
desc: Explores how theories of aesthetics have struggled with notions of beauty, value, pleasure, and pain in the human communicative experience.

name: Rhetoric and Black Culture
desc: This course will examine the manner in which Black aesthetic and intellectual expressions and controversies function as public discourse in cultural politics.

name: Rhetorics of Space and Place
desc: Considers place in relation to space and time.  Primary concentration on implications of theorizing place as communicative practice rather then communicative context.

name: Rhetoric and Public Memory
desc: Addresses the fundamentally rhetorical character of public memory.  Analyzes theoretical presuppositions about memory.  Openings for rhetorizing memory.

name: Topics in Rhetorical and Cultural Studies
desc: Special problems in rhetorical and cultural studies.  May be repeated.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Research Practicum
desc: Permission of the internship coordinator. Individualized practical experience supervised by a faculty advisor and by the departmental coordinator of internships. May be repeated.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Directed Research
desc: Permission of the instructor.  Individual research on a problem defined by the graduate student and graduate faculty member in conference. May be repeated.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Research Practicum in Communication Studies
desc: Individualized practical research.

name: Proseminar in Professional Development
desc: This course advances graduate students' exposure to academic resources and common norms, practices, and procedures related to academic professionalism in Communication Studies.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 2 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Master's (Non-Thesis)
desc: Focuses on the development of a master's project or a major paper other than a thesis
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.
